description: Search for the holy grail guarded by the great dragon Smaug (where have I heard that name before...) This particular game is one of the earliest implementations on a home computer of the mainframe game DND, developed for PLATO in the early 70s. This is one of the earliest Dungeons & Dragons type games available for home computers, and may even predate Temple of Apshai.
title: Dungeon of Death

description:
Air Attack is a one-key action game; the player has to drop bombs to clear all blocks so it can land safely at the bottom of the screen.

A plane moves from left to right across the screen, slightly descending every time it wraps back to the left side. The player has to press the spacebar to drop bombs to bombard the mountains below so the plane won't crash into them. You can only drop one bomb at a time, so they have to be dropped carefully as to clear the tallest bricks first. The level is completed when all blocks are removed and the plane has landed safely at the bottom of the screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: A bomb hits the ground, an asterisk represents the explosion

title: Air Attack

description: The game's subtitle is "take the enemy by storm" and for once it isn't simply figurative language! In this whimsical take on the artillery duel, two human players assume control of two rustic shacks, one on each side of the screen. Across the top wanders a lonely cloud, innocuous but full of hostile potential. Apparently the denizens of the houses are mad scientists with fully-functional weather-controlling apparatus, since each turn one player gets to select a variety of weather -- Hail, Rain, Tornado or Lightning -- to inflict upon his or her opponent. Selecting a "charge" to assign the attack, based on the cloud's shifting location and a variable wind speed, the aggressor hopes to land a damaging strike upon their neighbour. The game is won when one side has successfully harnessed the forces of nature to completely dismantle the other's residence.
title: Weather War

description: Nazo no Enban AFO (Chiteki na Game) is a simple game where the player takes control of a person and must try to shoot down the AFO (a flying saucer) by sending up balloons. The player scores three points when he shoots down the AFO, but if the AFO hits the player he is beamed up and subsequently dropped down again and loses one point. There is also a time limit, but there are continues if the player wishes to play on with his earned points.

sample_screenshots.caption: I hit the alien on the head
I used up all my balloons, game over!

title: Nazo no Enban AFO (Chiteki na Game)

description: Aliens! is a shooter in the vein of Space Invaders. Aliens will spawn infinitely at the top of the screen and move down in a straight line. The player moves a tank left and right to line up their shots. When the player dies, he or she gets to see how many aliens were killed and how many shots were fired.
title: Aliens!

description:
In Bat! the player takes control of an radio controlled electronic bat. The objective is to stay alive by consuming calories in the form of bugs present on the screen. Different bugs give different amounts of calories and some are even harmful to the bat. The final score is the time spent in play. Calories are slowly used up so that new ones have to be found constantly.

To control the bat the player must apply force in one of four directions. Gravity will continuously pull the bat downwards.
title: Bat!

description:
Blackjack is a digital version of the classic card game. The player can bet each turn up to 25000 dollars. The player has infinite money to spend, so he cannot go bankrupt. The bank is played by the computer.

Normal blackjack rules apply. This includes insurance; whenever the dealer draws an ace as his first card the player may start an insurance side-bet which he wins if the dealer gets blackjack.

sample_screenshots.caption: I need to decide on a side-bet

title: Blackjack

description: Canyon is a space ship simulation where the player must navigate through a canyon. The player can use the keyboard or joystick to avoid canyon walls in this vertically scrolling game. Depending on how well the player does he or she will earn a rank ranging from beginner to 5 star general.

sample_screenshots.caption: Background story. Funnily it mentions that there indeed are no space canyons...

title: Canyon

description: Checkers! allows the player to play the classic board game against the computer. Instead of selecting tiles with a cursor, all tiles have a number. The player simply types the number of the tile on which the pieces are and where to move them. There are no options to be set and for the computer to calculate its turn can take several seconds. The computer will beep once it is your turn again.
title: Checkers!

description:
Diamond Hunt II is a re-make of Diamond Hunt. In the game the player (Q) can walk around generated levels in search of diamonds marked by the letter Z. However the player must be careful of mines that are not visible but can be detected when they are nearby. The player has shields which can withstand only a limited number of explosions. The goal is to earn as much money before the player dies.

There are also walls which can block the player. Walls can be destroyed by using the disruptor weapon. The weapon has limited ammo which is increased by collecting crystals or completing a level by moving to the exit marked by the letter A. The disruptor also disables nearby mines.
title: Diamond Hunt II

description:
Dungeon is a Roguelike game. Like other games in this genre the player explores a dungeon in a top-down view and must collect loot and kill enemies to progress.

Each dungeon is generated randomly and only becomes visible during exploration. The player can only see one tile far. When encountering a monster the game automatically determines whether the player wins the fight or not, and (if the player survives) how much hitpoints he or she loses.

sample_screenshots.caption: Time to fire up the grill!
My very first dungeon. A wyvern is right on my tail...

title: Dungeon

description: Everest is a mountain climbing game in which the player must try to climb Mount Everest. The mountain is shown from the side and filled with numbers. Each number corresponds with the amount of strength it costs to climb to that spot. The player can move in eight directions with the numeric pad. Judging from the numbers the player must find the less intensive route to the top. Additional dangers include blizzards that roam the mountainsides and avalanches. The player can also fall a certain distance from time to time. Getting caught in a blizzard, like moving itself costs energy. When all energy is depleted the game is over. The player is rated by how far he or she climbed. The game keeps an average rating of all previous attempts.

sample_screenshots.caption: Uh oh... Didn't get very far.
So that's what that bright thing is!

title: Everest

description:
Fball is a turn-based American football game. Each turn the player must say what to do. There are thirteen actions in total, seven offensive and six defensive:

Offensive actions:

  • Run
  • Sweep
  • Screen pass
  • Long Pass
  • Punt
  • Field Goal
  • Timeout

Defensive actions:

  • Hold
  • Normal
  • Blitz
  • Intercept
  • Punt Return
  • Block Kick
  • Timeout

The player can play against another player or against the computer. The field is shown on the screen as well as the yard line at which the ball is, but no players are visible.

sample_screenshots.caption: The descriptions really try to make the best of it.
Ok, a bit too early perhaps

title: Fball

description: Fifteen is a simple sliding puzzle. The game doesn't feature much in the way of graphics as each tile simply has a number from one to fourteen, with the blank tile being fifteen. The game tracks how many moves it takes you to complete the puzzle.
title: Fifteen

description:
Fire! is a firefighting simulation in which the player is in control of a helicopter and must douse the fire that takes a grip on one (or more if you don't watch out) flats.

The player can move the helicopter in four directions and also hover in place. Using the water cannon the player can douse flames. Water is in limited supply, but one of the rooftops allows the player to replenish the water supply. The fire, like a real fire, will slowly and erratically expand in all directions. The player wins when the fire is put out, but loses if unsuccessful within three minutes.

sample_screenshots.caption: The fire has already spread to the next building
Start of the game. First have to fly to the fire

title: Fire!

description: Lander is an adaptation of Lunar Lander. In this version you don't have to find solid ground, but you must make sure to not crash into the surface. In the game the lander starts at 52,800 feet above the surface and the player must make sure to land at a reasonable falling speed, to make sure the lander doesn't crash. The player can perform thrust in nine different quantities using the numeric keypad to reduce falling speed. There is only limited fuel, meaning the player can't simply go down in a leisurely pace.

sample_screenshots.caption: Closer to the ground the altitude meter changes scale

title: Lander

description:
LEM is an alternative version of Lander. Both games are based on Lunar lander. Both Lander and LEM share the same controls, but the graphical implementation is completely different. Where in Lander the space ship is shown stationary, with only an altitude meter changing, here the space ship moves down along the altitude meter.

This version also features more advanced graphics.

sample_screenshots.caption: Whoopsie... The game automatically closes when you fail.

title: LEM

description: Nab! bears similarities with Pac-Man. The player must clear the screen of "+"-shaped items to score points. But an AI player also roams the field. The game world consists of a simple maze with different lanes. The player can only switch lanes at predefined locations. This means he or she is vulnerable to encountering the AI player when inside a lane.
title: Nab!

description:
In Shark the player takes on the role of a killer shark at a public swimming beach. The goal is to kill as many swimmers before they escape to the beach or divers catch the shark. The player must also look out for traps.

At the start of the game the player can decide how many swimmers, traps and divers will be present.

sample_screenshots.caption: Just a nice day at the beach...

title: Shark

description: This version of Super Trek features different graphics and one additional weapon. The player can utilize corbomite which destroys the entire quadrant (meaning you have to warp-speed your ass out of there). Additionally the player can request a damage report to get a detailed report of the ship's status.

sample_screenshots.caption: In this version the commands are conveniently always in view

title: Super Trek /16KNR

description:
Star Force is very similar to the arcade game Star Fire. The player must shoot TIE Fighters from a first-person perspective. Using the numeric keys the player can rotate the view into any directions. Each time the player hits a TIE Fighter it will explode and the player will receive points. If the player holds the targeting reticule on a TIE Fighter for a while it will lock-on, any hit after that will automatically hit. The TIEs also shoot back. Although the player cannot die from hits, it does reset the score multiplier. The game is over when the player is out of fuel.

The player must be conservative with lasers as each shot will build up heat, if the player fires too many lasers in a row the firing mechanism will overheat, leaving the player vulnerable for a while. The player can also control the speed of his spacecraft to either slow or fast. In the HUD a small radar view is visible which shows where TIE Fighters are about.

sample_screenshots.caption: Locked, but my weapons have overheated!
The explosions are not bad for BASIC

title: Star Force

description:
This title contains two games:

  • Tunnel Vision is a maze game, with the simple goal for the player to escape the maze. The maze is shown in 3D vector art, a style later employed in the early Ultima and Wizardry games.

  • Kat and Mouse is also a maze game, but shows the maze from a top-down perspective. The object here is to escape the maze as the mouse while avoiding the cat.

sample_screenshots.caption: Found the exit in Tunnel Vision!
The map showing our current location and where we've already been in Tunnel Vision.

title: Tunnel Vision and Kat and Mouse

description: Yahtzee is a computer adaptation of the famous dice game. In this adaptation, the player(s) get to roll five dice and you get to re-roll any number of them up to two times in order to make a nice set. Sets include ones through sixes, three of a kind, four of a kind, full house, small and large straight, Yahtzee (five of a kind) and chance. If the ones through sixes add up to more than three times each of those numbers, the player receives a bonus. The game can be played with up to four players throwing dice in turns.

sample_screenshots.caption: These are helpful, until you learn the abbreviations by heart
My first roll. A small straight...
This looks like typical chance to me

title: Yahtzee

description: Ambush is a two player turn-based strategy game. It has very simple rules. Both players move about on the same grid, each turn a player may first move to an adjacent tile (including diagonal tiles) and after that bomb a tile. A bombed tile becomes inaccessible. The first player who is completely surrounded by bombed tiles loses.

sample_screenshots.caption: Seems like a clear victory for Schmobygamer...

title: Ambush!

description:
Baseball is a baseball simulation for two players. The game uses a top-down perspective and single-screen multiplayer. The batting player has two actions at his or her disposal: swinging the bat and make the third base runner hold up. Batting his to happen at the exact time the ball goes over the plate.

The pitching player can throw six different balls (slow and fast curve, straight and knuckler) and in addition can move the out-fielders left or right to try and catch the ball.

Normal baseball rules apply, but there's no (visible) player stats.

sample_screenshots.caption: See that ball go past first!
Are they cheering for my player?

title: Baseball

description:
Blockade Special! is an action game that bears similarities with Snake. In the game the player has to escape from a maximum security prison.

The game uses a top-down view and the player can move in eight directions. The avatar uses a trail that automatically keeps moving. If the player maneuvers the avatar to a space it has already been the player dies. Unlike in Snake where the length of the trail is finite, here the trail keeps in place until the next level. The player can opt for a hard mode to make the trail invisible. In this case the player must remember exactly where he or she has threaded.

Like in Snake the player can collect items to score points, in addition the player earns points for each step the avatar makes. After sixty seconds robots will set electric fences on random positions of the game field, these have to be avoided. If the player lasts out for a while longer, he or she advances to the next level.

The player can switch between nine different difficulties. Higher difficulties result in a higher movement speed, meaning the player runs out of space to walk on quicker.

Sometimes the player is rewarded with a bonus stage where quick reflexes can earn additional points.

sample_screenshots.caption: That's one spade I'm not going to collect anymore...
Being conservative with space is the way to go

title: Blockade Special!

description:
Capture! is an action puzzle game in which the player is chased by wild beasts and must try to trap them by pushing boxes in their way. The beasts have very simple AI routines where they always try to move closer to the player. This behaviour can be exploited to create traps for the beasts to walk in.

The game uses a top down perspective. The player can move in eight directions. Any box the player hits will be pushed in the direction the player is walking. The player is strong enough to push an infinite number of boxes, allowing the player to push an entire wall of boxes.

There are nine different difficulty levels which influence the speed with which the wild beasts move.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game start. I'm the circle. The Asterisks are the wild beasts
Luring a beast in my trap

title: Capture!

description: In Demon! the player takes on the role of a sorcerer with the task to recapture demons that have escaped during an accident. For the duration of the spell the player must capture demons, which will appear one at a time. To capture the demons the player can move in eight directions and push boxes to block their way or completely trap them.
title: Demon!

description: Dot Racer is a racing game without any rules. There's no finish line nor rules. The player can simply race a car by setting the speed (1 through 9) and steering with the < and > keys. The game is made in such a way that new tracks can easily be added to the BASIC code.
title: Dot Racer

description:
Gammon allows the player to play the classic board game Backgammon against the Commodore PET computer. All basic rules apply in this strategic game where players have to try to move their pieces off the board and prevent the opponent from doing so.

The game uses a text parsing system to determine moves the player wants to make.

sample_screenshots.caption: The PET took its first turn
The short introduction actually goes on for seven pages

title: Gammon

description: Lawn! is a simple lawn mowing game. The player controls a motorized lawnmower and must try to mow the entire lawn before fuel runs out. The lawn is shown in a top-down view and tiles which aren't mowed are shown green. The player can simply move in four directions with the numeric pad. The player can choose between 10 skill levels, each level makes the lawnmower slightly faster and thus harder to control, in addition the player is given less fuel to complete the job with. Once in a while the player stumbles on a patch of weed, the lawnmower will stall for a second and stop in place.

sample_screenshots.caption: I managed to mow the entire lawn
Mowing my way through the lawn

title: Lawn!

description: Othello is a computer conversion of the classic board game of the same name (also known as Reversi). In this version two players can compete against each other. The players need to fill in the name of the field to which they wish to move (for example 7E) using the keyboard. The game does not automatically detect if a player can no longer make a move.
title: Othello

description:
In Planet Probe the player controls a space ship and must try to get close enough to a planet to make a proper picture. Additionally, the player must escape gravity again and fly out of the screen. The spaceship has eight thrusters controlled by the numeric keypad, each pointing in a different direction. The picture is taken automatically when the player gets close enough.

After successfully completing the mission twice, the game's difficulty increases as the player is challenged to take a picture of a more massive planet. After that, the player is then allowed to choose how massive the planet is.
title: Planet Probe

description:
Racer! is a top-down racing game. The game features randomized racetracks. The player can set some of the parameters to determine the difficulty: the width of the track and the number of potholes.

The player has only four controls, gas, brake, steer left and right. Using the steering the player must avoid running off the track and avoid potholes. By giving more gas, the player goes faster, but this also means quicker responses are required to steer correctly.

After crashing or finishing a track the game reports the distance traveled, the average speed and the time taken. The player can opt to race the same track again or randomly generate a new one.

sample_screenshots.caption: Racing! The asterisk is a pothole.
This many potholes? Must be the U.S.

title: Racer!

description:
In Rescue! the player is tasked with rescuing people... in space!

A shuttle in the form of a ball will enter at the top of the screen, flying horizontally. When the player presses a button it will leave a square behind and drop down. Using the 4 and 5 keys the player can nudge it to the left and right. Somewhere on the ground, there's a single safe spot to land. The player must reach that spot while avoiding moving particles. Once landed, one of the people will load on-board, after which the player must fly back to the square tile, again avoiding the moving particles.

The player has a limited number of shuttles and each level has a number of people to be rescued. Each level features more floating particles, making the journey more difficult. There are also three different difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: Higher difficulty. I only have a single shuttle to work with in addition to the increased number of obstacles
I missed the platform and crashed

title: Rescue!

description: Safe! is a safe cracking game. The player is presented with a safe which is locked by a random combination. The combination is in the form of four letters which have to be reached by turning left or right. The player hears sound cues when the right letter presents itself. There is a time limit within the player must crack the safe.
title: Safe!

description:
Space Shooter is a first person shooter written in BASIC. The controls are quite simple, using the numeric keypad the player can aim left, right, up and down and pressing "f" fires lasers. The goal for the player is to hit the spaceship that is flying in front of his or hers.

The spaceship will move about the screen quite erratically and using the movement controls the player must try to fix it in the targeting reticule. Once there the player should fire to destroy the ship. Once the ship is destroyed the player gains one point and a new ship will spawn. If the player fails to destroy the ship after the time limit is exceeded the computer gains a point. The player can play as long as he or she wishes on four different difficulty levels.
title: Space Shooter

description:
Tank! is a two player action game. Both players control a tank in top down view. The tank can be moved in eight directions, can fire shots and lay mines. Each player has a single mine and six shots per tank. Mines become invisible once laid down. There are also obstructions on the map, they can be shot away. But when all shots have been used up, the tank is rendered useless and is destroyed.

Each player has a limited number of tanks. The first to lose all tanks loses the game. There are ten difficulty levels which determine the amount of shots available and the amount of obstructions on the map.
title: Tank!

description:
Titrator is a simulation game in which you perform titration. The object is to find out how strong the given caustic solution is. This is done by titrating with HCl. When the solution gets a neutral acidity the indicator will change color.

The player can add HCl in a continuous flow or drop by drop. The game automatically does the math. You can fail by adding too much HCl.

sample_screenshots.caption: Not my idea of a good time...

title: Titrator

description:
Mission 2001 is a clone of Asteroids, dumbed down to the capabilities of the Commodore PET.

Like in the original the player controls a spaceship and can thrust forward and rotate. The player must fire on ever-moving asteroids who break up into smaller pieces when shot. When in trouble the player can use hyperspace to escape to another random location on the screen.

In this version the ship instantly brakes when the player lets go of the thruster and everything (including bullets) can only strictly move in eight directions.

sample_screenshots.caption: At this point actually hitting something becomes a real chore
Asteroids can move through each other

title: Mission 2001

description:
Epidemic is a simulation game in which the player can set a number of starting variables and then watch in a real-time simulation what the results are.

The game simulates a disease epidemic. The disease is non-fatal and people who've had the disease become immune. The player can set the number of inhabitants of the island where the disease breaks out, the number of people initially infected and the contagion time. The simulation shows a top-down view of the island with the population randomly moving about. When infectious people come in contact with uninfected people they become infected.

After the disease has run its course, the player is presented with day-by-day graphs of what happened.

sample_screenshots.caption: Let's try a larger population and a longer contagion time!
When the first contagion time is over already a large amount of people have been infected
The resulting data is what this game is all about

title: Epidemic

description: In Outpost the player is under constant attack of enemies in all directions. The game uses a top-down grid in which the player always inhabits the center and enemies enter the grid around the edges. There can be a maximum of four different enemies at a time. Each turn the player can select a weapon and fire on an enemy of choice. The player may also opt to recharge lost hitpoints. The player has different hitpoints for different systems. Whether the player hits or misses a shot is determined randomly. The enemies obviously fire back.

sample_screenshots.caption: Destroyed an enemy with a torpedo.

title: Outpost

description:
Pinball is a simple pinball game with a single table. The ball can only travel at eight different angles, so it doesn't move very realistically when colliding with round objects. Bumpers score points as well as the spade, diamond, club and heart in the middle of the field. Collecting all four of those grants an extra ball on top of the five balls the player starts with.

There are no paddles until the player hits a button, so good timing is required.

sample_screenshots.caption: Graphics loaded, ball in the game
Bumpers change colour when hit. I collected a spade and heart.

title: Pinball

description:
In this faithful recreation of the original Mainframe game, the player hunts Wumpi. The game is presented in text only. The player walks through a cave system and must hunt Wumpi by shooting them with arrows. Each turn the player can move to any adjacent room, fire an arrow in any adjacent room, look up the remaining number of arrows, exit a cave (when near an exit) or show instructions.

If the player walks into the same room as a Wumpus it's game over. There are also other traps: superbats that will send the player to a different cave and bottomless pits that kill. From time to time earthquakes can occur which can block or open certain passages between rooms.

At any time the player can sense the hazards which are in adjacent rooms, but not in which adjacent room they are.

sample_screenshots.caption: Why not stop for lunch, eh?

title: Twonky

description: Artillery is an adaptation of the well known formula. Players take turn firing their artillery shots at the enemy. They only have to provide an angle and amount of gunpowder (for distance). The wind changes strength and direction each turn which has to be taken into calculation. The levels are randomly generated between every game and shells that are fired leave a small crater. If a player hits the other player the game is over. This version features only two player hot-seat play.

sample_screenshots.caption: In this generated level the players have to shoot over a steep mountain

title: Artillery

description: Breakout is a recreation of the original arcade game. In the game the player moves the paddle at the bottom of the screen and has to try and keep the ball from hitting the bottom. At the top of the screen there are stones which disappear when the ball hits them. Removing stones is worth points. The higher up the stone is located, the bigger its value. The player has several lives before he or she goes game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: When the game is over the ball will bounce around the screen continuously
Since I couldn't get my controls to work I'm kind of helpless...

title: Breakout

description: Chess Game allows players to play chess on the Commodore Pet. The normal rules apply and the game keeps the score and number of "checks" during a game. There is no computer AI and the only multiplayer option is hotseat. Moves are made using a text parser.
title: Chess Game

description: In spite of what the name might imply, Dominos is not an adaptation of the tile-laying game Dominoes, but is in fact a Light Cycle game. It's an unofficial port of the Atari original. One player can take it up against the computer or play against another player. The domino lines continuously increase in length, causing the screen to slowly fill up. The goal is to make the opponent run into something, which scores a point.

sample_screenshots.caption: Difficulty selection for the AI opponent

title: Dominos

description: Dragon Island is a simple game that bears some similarities with Hunt the Wumpus. The goal is to slay a dragon with a spear. Each turn the player may throw his spear in one of ten caves. If the dragon is in the chosen cave he dies, if he's in an adjacent cave he'll snort. The dragon can also change cave. Between each throw the player must retrieve the spear. If the dragon in the mean time moved into the cave, the player dies. The player also dies if he or she fails to kill the dragon before the clock strikes eight.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is pretty much all there is to this game
The program unceremoniously ends itself when you die

title: Dragon Island

description:
Football allows two players to compete in a match of American Football. The players can determine the actual length of the game as well as the names for the teams. The game is played by selecting an action each turn. Once both players have selected an action an animation is shown in which the action is played out.

Offensive actions are:

  • Short pass
  • Long pass
  • Off tackle
  • Reverse
  • Field goal
  • Punt
  • Sweep

Defensive actions are:

  • Blitz
  • 3-4
  • 4-3
  • Prevent
  • Stack

sample_screenshots.caption: Not enough football knowledge to remember what's going on here :P

title: Football

description:
Golf is a textual golfing game. Each turn the player must select a club to strike the ball with. There's a wide variety of clubs to choose from. With certain clubs the player can choose the amount of power behind his or her swing. The game automatically aims for the player.

There are multiple holes to play on and the player can set a handicap for him- or herself to change the difficulty of the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: You must know a bit about golf to know which clubs to use

title: Golf

description: In this adaptation of the traditional board game Gomoku, the player can play against the AI. Normal rules apply. Each turn players place their pieces on the 14x14 board in an attempt to reach five in a row. Rows may be attained horizontally, vertically and diagonally. There are three different AIs to play against: a cautious, aggressive and balanced version. The player may also choose to go first or not and which color to play.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game is controlled with the numeric keypad
I don't really know what I'm doing :)

title: Gomoku

description: Guess It is based on a traditional magic trick with cards, where the player has to think of any number between 1 and 63 and the magician is going to guess it. In this case the computer is the magician and he uses six cards with numbers on them of which the player must say whether the number is on it. After answering six times the computer will tell which number the player was thinking of.

sample_screenshots.caption: *Gasp* ... too bad I already learned this trick with the magician kit I had as a little kid.

title: Guess It

description:
Horserace! is not unsurprisingly all about horse racing. Instead of racing, the player(s) are betting however. Each of the up to six players start with $100 to try and make their fortune. Each round various horses will race. The player can bet a desired amount on each of the horses of which the odds are shown in a table. Depending when the horse finishes it pays up a different amount.

The races themselves are fully animated where all horses will race across a scrolling screen to the finish line.
title: Horserace!

description:
TRON: Light Cycle Game is an adaptation of the Light Cycle sequence in the film. In this adaptation the player competes against a single AI opponent. The game keeps no score, but instantly offers rematches when either the player or AI crashes. The AI has a lot of different openings, leading to some surprising matches.

The player can use the < and > buttons to steer left or right. When someone hits a wall or a trail left behind by one of the light bikes that player or AI crashes and loses the game. The player can also toggle the speed between slow and fast.

sample_screenshots.caption: Is this the most awesome title screen on the PET or what!?
I crashed, the controls aren't very responsive.
Instruction screen, again with some detailed graphics
I can get him locked in a small space if I can make this turn right...
The actual game graphics are a bit of a disappointment

title: Tron: Light Cycle Game

description:
The Mad Bomber is a single-button action game in which the player must drop bombs on targets. The game is shown in view from the side and the player's aeroplane will move across the screen at different heights. The player must drop bombs on various targets which are rated in importance (shown by their number). The numbers directly translate into the score for the player.

The player has twenty bombing runs to score points in, but if the player misses more than three times, the game is over as well. There's two difficulty levels, easy and hard. In hard mode there is a death-beam with sensors. If the player accidentally hits the sensors, the death-beam will fire straight up. If the death-beam hits the player, it's game over as well.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bombs will fly diagonally, because they retain some of the plane's momentum.

title: The Mad Bomber

description:
One of many conversions of the classic game Mastermind for the Commodore PET. The player has to guess a code of numbers selected by the computer. Players can determine for themselves both the amount of eligible numbers and the length of the code. There is no limit to the amount of guesses the player makes. It is also possible to give shorter guesses. For example, if the code consists of six letters, guess a code of only three to see if you have the first three right. Or even guess for longer codes to see if certain numbers are in the code.

After each guess the player is shown the "blacks" and "whites", respectively correct numbers in the right position and correct numbers in the wrong position. When the player has guessed the correct code, he or she is shown the total number of guesses it took and is asked to continue a new game with the set rules or redefine the rules.

sample_screenshots.caption: After the embarrassing first game, I decided to put some effort in it and got the code in seven guesses.
The game even accepts codes that are too long

title: Master Mind

description: In this Mastermind conversion for the Commodore PET the rules of Mini Mastermind by board game publisher Invicta are used (although instead of eight guesses the player has infinite). The player must guess a code of four pegs which can consist of any of six colors. After each guess the player learns the number of "black" and "white" pegs, respectively colors in the right position and colors which are in the code, but on a different position. There are no options that can be set for variations in the rules.
title: Mastermind

description:
Adventure 1: Cavern of Riches is a typical text adventure game in which the player must try to collect the twelve different treasures hidden in the game world. They must be returned to their proper place.

The player can move around in all directions and can pick-up and manipulate items. Simple puzzles must be solved, but there is little to no story. The game does feature a save and load system to restore from an earlier game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Don't expect much flavour in this game, there's dozens of locations with this exact text
You can opt to load a previous game
Errr, in which direction is that?

title: Adventure 1: Cavern of Riches

description: Adventure 2: The Great Pyramid, like its predecessor, is a text adventure game with little to no story. The aim in the game is to find a number of treasures that are scattered around the game world. The world comprises a great pyramid and its immediate surrounding desert. The game features save and restore functionality.

sample_screenshots.caption: After the gate opens a face appears...
Gosh, it just popped up out of nowhere!
It's possible to save and restore
The game neglects to tell insignificant details like the huge pyramid right next to me.

title: Adventure 2: The Great Pyramid

description: Space! is an arcade first person shooter. The player sits inside a spacecraft and can rotate the view in any direction. The aim is to shoot as many enemy spacecraft as possible. Each shot costs energy. When the energy level gets too low the game ends. In addition to firing the laser, the ship also drains energy automatically, creating a time limit within which the player can operate. Enemies don't fire back.

sample_screenshots.caption: Firing the laser doesn't result in any spectacular effects...

title: Space!

description:
The most likely incorrectly spelled Torpedeo is a single-button action game in which the player must destroy submarines. The player sits in a B-29 submarine hunter and must launch torpedoes at the right moment. Both the plane and submarine move in different directions and the torpedo moves in a diagonal line, making aiming more difficult.

The game never ends, but the game keeps track of how many submarines the player hit and how many times the player missed. The game also calculates hit percentage.

sample_screenshots.caption: The players plane keeps flying from left to right. When hitting the right border it spawns on the left again. Not firing during a run anything doesn't change the score.
A hit. There are sound effects, to differentiate between hit and miss.

title: Torpedeo

description: Acrobat II is a variant of Circus/Clowns that is very similar to the Commodore 64 and VIC 20 versions. In the game the player must position a see-saw in order to keep an acrobat in the air. The player scores points by popping balloons that are placed near the ceiling of the circus. In addition the player scores points for each jump and can score various bonus points. If the acrobat touches the floor the game is over and he's carried off in an ambulance.
title: Acrobat II

description: Casino Blackjack allows up to five players to play blackjack against a virtual bank. Players play in turns and can bet, hit or fold, double down (double the bet, but only receive one extra card), insurance bet (when the dealer starts with an ace) and split pairs. The players can also count cards, because the game remembers which cards have been used. After a certain number of hands the deck is shuffled again, or the player can order it to be shuffled at any time.
title: Casino Blackjack

description: Bomber is a top-down shooter in which the player takes on the role of a bombardier of a B-29 Bomber plane. The game uses a scrolling top-down view of enemy territory with various structures popping up from time to time. The aim of the game is to hit as many structures as possible within the two minute time limit. The plane will fly along the river line where barges, hydro-plants and factories have to be destroyed. The player can aim to the left or right and fire as many bombs as he or she wishes. At the end of the time limit the player receives a score.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bomb just about to close in on the barge
The river swerves in many directions

title: Bomber

description:
Crazy Balloon is a conversion of the Arcade game of the same name. In the game the player has to guide a balloon through a course. Bumping into any wall pops the balloon.

There are two lines the player can move through to add points. Additional bonus points are rewarded if the player moves through both.

To thwart the player there's an enemy that moves around and can't be touched either. If the player doesn't move the balloon for five seconds it pops as well.

The balloon has its own will and will automatically float in various directions, so it has to be kept in check.
title: Crazy Balloon

description: Donuts is a representation of the Tower of Hanoi mathematical puzzle. The game only features one size of tower (three sections). The rules are as normal, the player may move only one of the sections at a time and place them on one of three slots. The three sections have different sizes and larger sections cannot be on top of smaller sections. The player must relocate the whole tower to a different slot. The game keeps track of the number of moves.

sample_screenshots.caption: Not very good, because the numbers had me confused
The game asks for your name, but strangely never uses it again...
The fact that both the disks and slots are named after numbers is thoroughly confusing

title: Donuts

description:
This appropriately named Flight Simulator features only the instrument panel and not an actual world to fly in. The game starts with take off and the player can fly around for as long as the fuel lasts.

The player can at any time set the following functions:

  • Throttle
  • Ailerons
  • Elevator

And in addition try to initiate a landing procedure.

An instrument panel shows the player's fuel, airspeed, altitude, heading (in degrees) and vertical speed at any time. When the player does things wrong the plane crashes.

sample_screenshots.caption: The instrument panel shows all you need to know
Trying out what the L function does...
The game should feature instructions, but my version didn't...

title: Flight Simulator

description:
Joust is a jousting game in which two players must joust it out on horses. Players can control the location of both their lance and their shield. They must try to block the other player's lance with their shield by placing it high, middle or low and in addition try to hit the other player with their lance by placing it in one of those same locations. A player cannot place his or her lance and shield in the same location.

In the game, the horses move towards each other automatically. The players can move their equipment at any time, making last second adjustments.

sample_screenshots.caption: That's what BASIC horses look like!
The ever ongoing battle between Mobygamer and Schmobygamer

title: Joust

description: Laser Tanks is multiplayer tank battling game. Two players have to duke it out in either an easy or hard maze. Players can move one tank at a time and move them forward, backward and rotate them into any direction. They can only fire straight ahead. Each player has thirteen tanks and thus thirteen lives. The first player to kill all the other player's tanks wins.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is where it got confusing
Like most basic games, the game really plays in a grid

title: Laser Tanks

description:
M-Maze is a simple maze game using a top-down view. The game generates random mazes and drops the player in the middle. It's up to the player to find the exit as quickly as possible. When an exit is found the game notifies the player how many seconds it took him or her and then generates a new maze.

When moving around, the game actually scrolls the maze, instead of moving the player's character. The game loops horizontally and vertically, so that the entire maze can be seen at any given moment, but when near the edges it will be broken up for added difficulty.

sample_screenshots.caption: I went completely in the wrong direction
The top, is actually the bottom of the maze and the left half the right end of the maze

title: M-Maze

description:
Simulation of Millikan Oil Drop Experiment is exactly that: a simulation of the experiment performed by Robert Millikan and Harvey Fletcher in 1909 to measure the elementary electric charge.

In the game the player can increase and decrease the voltage of the experiment with increments of one, ten or a hundred. Once the player is certain the charged oil drop is stable, he or she can press A for analysis. The player can also determine the percentage error by pressing P.

The game features five experiments after which the computer tries to calculate "e" (the charge of a single electron).

sample_screenshots.caption: Take 2 parts voodoo and 1 part magic
The game features a lengthy explanation of the experiment...
Unfortunately when the action starts the game throws me an error...

title: Simulation of Millikan Oil Drop Experiment

description: Night Drive is a variant of the arcade game Night Driver. In the game the player must race for 90 seconds and try to score as many points by passing through checkpoints. The player can accelerate and steer both left and right. The player must stay on the road and avoid hitting traffic or face crashing the car.
title: Night Drive

description:
S-Racer is a top-down racing game with just a single track. The player controls a car (presumably) and must use the numeric keys to lead it to the finish. The car can move in eight different directions. If the player hits the side of the road the car explodes and the player must start over from the start.

The car can come to a standstill instantly and only moves if the player holds a button. There is also no acceleration.

When the player reaches the finish line he or she gets to see how long it took him or her.
title: S-Racer

description:
Star Fighter is a shooter in which the player flies an X-Wing and must fire his two proton torpedoes into the ventilation shaft of the Death Star and subsequently escape out of the explosion radius. While reaching the shaft the player must also avoid T.I.E.s, not to be confused with TIE Fighters.

Neither the player, nor the enemies can fire lasers, but when the player collides with an enemy it's game over. When the player misses both torpedoes the game is also over.

sample_screenshots.caption: We can't stop here, this is TIE country!
Getting closer to the Death Star
My X-Wing is shown as the letter X!

title: Star Fighter

description: Tic Tac Toe allows the player to play Tic-Tac-Toe against the computer. The player and computer take turns place naughts and crosses in a three by three field. The goal is to get three in a row. The player can decide to go first or not.

sample_screenshots.caption: At least graphically, they tried to polish it up a bit
Most games will end in a stalemate

title: Tic Tac Toe

description:
Zap is a variant of Snake. In the game the player controls a "strange missle" (sic) that must hit targets. When it does, the missile grows bigger. The missile can move in eight directions and must not bump into itself or the borders of the screen. Targets will spawn at random locations and intervals.

The player collects points when hitting targets and has six lives before he goes game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: You earn points for each target
There can be many targets at the same time on the screen, after a while they will also disappear

title: Zap

description:
Break-Out is a Break Out variant. The player controls a paddle at the bottom of the screen and must prevent a ball from hitting the floor and at the same time destroy bricks at the top of the screen by hitting them with said ball. Each destroyed brick scores points.

There are some subtle differences compared to the original game. The paddle is controlled slightly differently. Pressing either the left or right direction with Keypad 4 or 6 respectively moves the paddle in that direction, and the paddle keeps moving until it hits the side or the player presses 5. The game can also be played with Creative Software's joysticks.

When the ball hits a corner of a brick it will not bounce back and instead break through multiple rows, this makes it easier to get the ball above the rows of bricks. Because the game is written in BASIC the ball can only travel at a 45 degree angle, causing it to leave quickly as well.

The player starts with 10 lives with which to score points. There's no keeping of high-scores.
title: Break-Out

description: Bridge Bidding Trainer helps the player to learn bridge. In the game the player is continuously dealt hands and the player must say how much points his hand is worth and what he should bid. When the player does things wrong the computer will correct him. the player doesn't actually get to play bridge in this training program. On start-up the player can get a brief overview of the rules.
title: Bridge Bidding Trainer

description:
Buggy presents the player with seven math problems where the computer incorrectly calculates something. The player can ask the computer to solve certain equations in order to try and find out what the "bug" is. When the player thinks they have figured out what's wrong, they can challenge the computer. At this point the computer presents an equation and the player must predict the incorrect outcome the computer will give.

The player starts with 100 points and with each equation or try points are subtracted from the total. The aim of course is to score as many points as possible.

sample_screenshots.caption: I guess the game is kind of buggy, because this looks like a correct calculation to me...
My guess was wrong. I get to practice some more

title: Buggy

description:
PET Checkers allows the player to play checkers against the computer. The standard international rules apply: taking turns the player may move any piece one tile diagonally as long as that tile is free. Normal pieces can only move towards the other player, but once a piece reaches the other side of the board, it is crowned and can from then on move in both directions. Pieces can be hit by being jumped over. The first player to lose all pieces loses the game.

The game keeps track of the time and uses field number input to determine moves.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the end it can get rather boring
I hit one of his pieces

title: PET Checkers

description:
In Forest the player assumes the role of a forest ranger and must determine the amount of diseased trees in the forest.

There are two play modes: a simulation mode and a game mode. In the simulation mode the player can set various variables such as the number of trees in the forest, the number of samples and the number of trees per sample. The player can either set the diseased amount themselves or guess at it from the sample results.

In the game mode, the player can only determine the amount of samples and the amount of trees per sample. Each sample costs a start-up sum and one additional dollar per tree in the sample. The idea is to estimate the diseased percentage as closely as possible. Every percentage away from the actual amount will cost the player additional money. Once an estimation is made, the game will also show the player what the computer would have guessed using its methods and what the costs would have been. The player must aim to have less costs as the computer.

sample_screenshots.caption: If you set the percentage in the setup there's no game at all

title: Forest

description:
Qubic is based on the 1953 Parker Brothers board game of the same name. The game is identical to Connect Four except that it features a third dimension. This means that the player can try to get four in a row in nine different directions instead of three.

The board is 4x4x4 and player and computer take turns placing tokens. In the game each location has a numeric coordinate which the player must type in. There is no multiplayer possible.
title: Qubic

description:
One of many Hangman games for the Commodore PET. This particular version lets the player choose between five different categories of words: computers, sports, cars, nations and pot pourri. According to the help screen the player's best friend is arrested and charged with arson, treason, armed robbery, public drunkenness, murder, mayhem, ignorance and ugliness. To save him the judge has challenged the player to a game of hangman. The player is allowed to make eight mistakes before his friend ends up at the gallows.

Instead of a person and gallows slowly being drawn the gallows are already there and the person slowly moves the stairs towards it.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is actually more annoying than it may sound
It's a long road to the gallows

title: Hangman

description: One of many Hangman games for the Commodore PET. The player must guess the right word or face being hung on the gallows. In this version the player can make ten incorrect guesses and the hangman and gallows are drawn as expected. This version features no difficulties or categories.
title: Hang Man

description:
One of many Hangman games for the Commodore PET. The player must guess the right word or be hung on the gallows. In this version there are five difficulty levels and five different word sets. Depending on the difficulty the player may make more or fewer incorrect guesses.

The gallows are drawn by default, but the hangman is drawn bit by bit when the player makes an incorrect guess.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title screen (there was even a short animation)

title: Hangman

description: Butterfield Social & Recreational Club allows the player to partake in a virtual game of Black Jack. The player can set an amount of starting money and plays against the bank. Depending on the starting money the game cashes is a membership fee, which can get high depending on the amount of money the player enters. The remaining money determines the minimum bet. Casino rules such as insurance betting and splitting the cards don't apply in this simple rendition of the game. Cards are shuffled only when the deck is used up, so the player can try to count cards.

sample_screenshots.caption: Luck is not on my side today...

title: Butterfield Social & Recreational Club

description: Keno is a simulation of the casino game. The player determines the amount of money he or she wants to start with and then picks the amount of numbers he or she wants to select. The maximum possible is fifteen numbers. The numbers are between 1 and 80. The computer picks 20 numbers at random. If enough numbers match the player is rewarded with money, else the initial bet is lost. The fewer numbers the player picks, the lower the chance of a match, but the higher the turnout.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game highlights the random generated numbers one at a time.

title: Keno

description:
Life is a simulation of Conway's Game of Life. The player can draw his or her own patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.

The player can let the simulation play out, pause, reset, place cells and clear the screen.
title: Life

description: Mousemaze is a very simple maze game. At the start of the game the player gives a width and length for the maze, which the computer then generates. Once generated the player must navigate it using a top-down view. As the player starts moving ther is no stopping, so the player must avoid running into walls which ends the game. If the player reaches the end of the maze, points are rewarded based on the size of the maze and how long it took to complete.

sample_screenshots.caption: When you exit the maze you still need to walk to the square
I hit a wall, the game quits

title: Mousemaze

description:
Picture Kingdom is a version of Hamurabi with some simple graphics. The gameplay is completely identical.
Like in the original the game is played in turns and each turn the player must select:

  • How many acres of land to buy or sell
  • How many bushels of grain to feed to his people
  • How many bushels of grain to plant

Various random events will try to thwart the player's plans.
title: Picture Kingdom

description:
The Postperson's Route is a logical game in which the player must trace certain shapes. There are only two rules: The player must trace the shapes in a single continuous line, and the player cannot trace the same line more than once. The background story revolves around the player being a postman and having to find the most optimal route for his rounds.

There are eleven different puzzles to solve.
title: The Postperson's Route

description:
Ppong is based on the game Deflection. The basic rules are the same: the goal is to hit different targets with a ball. The player can deflect the path of the ball by placing deflectors. The ball normally travels in straight lines and when reaching the edge of the screen it will bounce back. Using the deflectors the ball can be redirected up and down again. The deflectors are placed at the current location of the ball, so timing is important.

New in this modification is the spawning of mines over time. The player must avoid hitting these with the ball. It's also possible to remove deflectors when near them.
title: Ppong

description: Sea Battle is a turn based strategy game for two players. Each player starts with a fleet of four ships: a battleship, a cruiser and two destroyers. The game world consists of a 10x10 grid and both players start in an opposite corner. Each turn a player can let all ships move one tile in any direction and fire on an enemy ship. The different ship classes have different hull strengths and ranges within which they can fire. The destroyers also carry two torpedoes which can be fired in addition to the normal attack. Ships also have limited ammunition meaning the player shouldn't waste anything on shots that are bound to miss.

sample_screenshots.caption: The fleets have moved, now entering the shooting phase
In spite of continuing fire no ships are down yet in turn 6

title: Sea Battle

description: Shoot is a single button game about timing. The player sees two lines moving across the screen in opposite directions. The player must hit "F" at the right moment to let one of the lines make a 90 degree turn with the aim of hitting the edge of the opposing line. With each try the distance between the the two lines is randomized. There's also four different game modes: horizontal, vertical, diagonal and mixed, each referring to the initial direction of the lines.
title: Shoot

description: TRON: Journey to the MCP is a maze game in which the player must find the exit. Added difficulty are distortions in the maze, which run in vertical lines. If the player - displayed as a dot in the top-down maze - resides in the distorted line he dies. Distortions run from top to bottom, making the bottom half of the maze safer, because it allows more maneuvering time. Vertical hallways are also more dangerous, because when inside of one a distortion cannot be outmaneuvered. The player must also not walk into wall as that instantly kills the player.

sample_screenshots.caption: A distortion at the other side of the maze
A very nice title screen, just like "TRON: Light Cycle Game"

title: Tron: Journey to the MCP

description:
In this translation of the classic board game Battleship the player can play with up to seven ships on an eight by eight grid. Game play is the same as normal. The player and the computer take turns by entering a coordinate. The game then announces if the shot was a hit or a miss. The goal is to sink all enemy ships. Ships take up three tiles in this game and to sink a tile all three tiles must be hit. Ships can be placed by the player and the player may do so at any location on the board, both horizontally and vertically as long as ships don't overlap or partially fall off the grid.

A later release of the game featured different length ships and different views for either player.
title: Battleship

description:
Cops is a Cops and Robbers game for two players. One player plays the robbers and the other the cops. The game takes place on a large grid representing the city's streets. The players take turns to make a move. The goal for the robbers is to remain untouched for fifteen turns, the goal for the cops is to catch the robbers. The robbers can move a single tile each turn, while the cops can move two tiles each turn. However, the cops have to obey the traffic rules of the city which can be summed up easily as: left turns are not allowed anywhere. It's also not possible to back up.

The game keeps track of the number of wins and losses.
title: Cops

description:
Defend! is a simple shooter game in which the player must fire incoming targets. Targets come from four different directions and the player must shoot them by pressing the respective direction on the key pad. The player has only limited energy and shields. Each shot costs energy and each missed target loses a shield point. When either runs out the game is over. The game keeps track of the best score the player received. Points are gained for each target shot. The player cannot move the avatar at the center of the screen.

The player can choose from nine different difficulty levels which determine the number of shields and energy available to the player.
title: Defend!

description: Drag! is an educational drag racing game. Up to four players must race to the finish line with their drag racing car. To do this they must solve simple arithmetic. The quicker they do so, the faster their car will go. The game is played in turns and each player receives a single sum each turn. When playing with just a single player the Commodore PET will take on the challenge for itself, although it will slow down to human calculating speeds to keep it fair.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game supports up to four players

title: Drag

description:
Enigma is a simulation of the type of message encryption devices used by the Germans from the 1920s until the end of World War II. In the game the player can opt to let the computer pick a setting or set the machine itself. Once set the user can type a sentence and encrypt his or her message.

The simulation does not decrypt, so the user or recipient must know how to decrypt using the message and the key given by the simulation.
title: Enigma

description: Gunner is a simple artillery game where two players must try to hit each other on a 10 by 10 grid. Neither player knows their position on the grid. The players take turn entering a coordinate, after which the game tells in which direction the shot was off using terms light, left, right, high or low. The first player to hit the other wins the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The grid only serves as a reference

title: Gunner

description: Heart Racer is a racing game in which the player must find the ♥ (heart) symbol. The player controls a car with the numeric pad. The game uses a top down view and levels that scroll along with the player are randomly generated. The goal is to reach the heart in as little time as possible. When colliding with walls, the car will bounce into random directions.

sample_screenshots.caption: The car leaves a trail to show where you've been.

title: Heart Racer

description: Lander X is a Lunar Lander variant. This version does not include graphics and uses textual input. Like other Lunar Lander games the player must successfully land a spacecraft on the Lunar surface. In order to do so the player must tell the computer the amount of thrust to apply in ten second intervals. Thrust values lie between 0 and 500 and push the spacecraft away from the planet's surface. Gravity will automatically pull the spacecraft towards the surface. The spacecraft has only limited fuel, constraining the player's options. The player is shown the current velocity, altitude and fuel levels at all times.
title: Lander X

description:
Life is a simulation of Conway's Game of Life. The player can draw his or her own patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.

The player can place cells and let the simulation play out and pause again.

What differentiates this version of Life from most other versions is that aside from cells the player can also place posts and holes. They remain static during the simulation, but cells behave differently around them.

sample_screenshots.caption: The cells roam all around the screen

title: Life

description:
Function Machine is an educational game in which the player inserts numbers into the machine. After a short animation of the machine crunching it will return a number. After the first inserted number, the player gets a chance to guess the outcome the machine will return for the next number the player inserts. The player can choose him- or herself which numbers to insert. There are five difficulty levels for different mathematics skill levels.

There are in-game instructions to change the source code to allow less or more tries within the user must correctly pick the answer.

sample_screenshots.caption: The machine is crunching the number 10 I put in

title: Function Machine

description: Ladder Mult. is an educational game in which the player must escape from a mad dog by solving multiplication sums. The player's character stands on a ladder and with each correct answer the player climbs one rung. With each incorrect answer the player drops a rung. Drop too far and the player gets eaten. Climb high enough and the player escapes. The game features no difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game is backwards compatible on the Commodore 64

title: ladder Mult.

description: Match is Concentration with a twist. Instead of having to find two identical pictures in a grid of tiles place face-down, the player must find two cards whose sum equals 63. Otherwise the rules are identical to Memory/Concentration, players take turns flipping a pair of tiles in the hope of having a match (the sum of 63 in this case). Each correct match earns the player a point and also an additional turn. The game can be played solitaire, with up to four players, or against the AI with up to nine different difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: When matches are made the tiles are removed
The PET also made an incorrect match
The AI has easy pickings at the end when most cards are known

title: Match

description: In this adaptation of the classic game Nim, the player and the computer take turns picking matches from three different stacks. The person to pick the last match wins. In a turn the player can pick any of the stacks to pick matches from (but never from multiple stacks) and pick as many matches as the player wants. The player can choose to play with between three and eight stacks and from six different AI difficulty levels. The game keeps track of the number of games played and won.
title: Nim

description:
Pegboard is a puzzle with eight pegs and nine tiles in a row. The goal of the puzzle is to move the four pegs on the left side to the right and the pegs on the right side to the left. The rules are as follows:

  • pegs that start on the left can only move right and vice versa
  • When a the tile adjacent to a peg is free the peg may move to that tile
  • If the tile adjacent to a peg is occupied by a peg the peg may jump over it if the tile behind it is free

The game can also solve itself when prompted.
title: Pegboard

description: Ping Pong is a Pong variation for two players. Both players can move their paddle up and down using the keyboard and bounce a ball back and forth. Failure to return the ball earns the other player a point. Players can determine beforehand how many points need to be scored to win the game. Depending on what part of the paddle the ball collides with the angle at which the ball reflects differs.
title: Ping Pong

description: Poker is a simple gambling game. The player can bet money and is dealt five cards. A pair returns the player his or her bet and anything better (using the default poker rules) earns a multiple of the initial bet. After receiving the initial cards the player can discard (up to five) some and gain new ones in return, but he or she cannot change the bet anymore.

sample_screenshots.caption: Pick cards to discard using the numbers 1 through 5

title: Poker

description: This Pong variant, like the classic Pong, allows two players to duke it out in a ball bouncing competition. Both players can move their paddle up and down in order to bounce back the ball. Whenever a player fails to bounce the ball back, the other player scores a point and the ball is reset. Once a player reaches 9 points, the game is over.
title: Pong

description: Seabattle is a parody of Sea Battle. The game starts out with exactly the same screen as the original, but quickly descends into parody. The game will refer to the player as Popeye and simulate the most absurd environments including monsters eating the enemy ships and the player being demoted to deck scrubber. There don't seem to be any tactics that'll prevent the player from failing horribly. Like the original game, the player controls a submarine and will be asked to perform a command each turn, which are selected by the numeric keypad. Commands include maneuvering, shooting, diving, etc.

sample_screenshots.caption: Damage immediately took out pretty much all my equipment. And one of the enemy ships just blew itself up running into its own mine.
Err, I guess it's scrubbing for me.
Start of the game. It's trying to pass itself off as Creative Computing's game of the same name

title: Seabattle

description: Slot Machine is a digital version of exactly that. The player can play on a single "one armed bandit", operated by a woman. To spin the wheels the player must pay one dollar, different combinations earn the player between 0 and 500 dollars. The player can stop at any time and the game keeps track of the player's virtual payments and winnings.

sample_screenshots.caption: Two of the wheels are spinning
$3 dollars! (winnings show the total winnings so far)
I guess I'm paid out in nickels...

title: Slot Machine

description: Thunt! is a maze game in which the player is tasked with finding treasure in a randomly generated maze. Enemies also roam the maze and will kill you when they come in contact. They do not know where the player is unless they have line of sight. The player is given the general coordinate of the treasure, but must still look around in that vicinity. When the player finds the treasure more points can be scored by solving an anagram puzzle. Finally the player must find the exit, which is again at a random location of which only a general coordinate is known. When the player escapes the game is over and his or her score is shown.

sample_screenshots.caption: The exit is located near the bottom left

title: Thunt!

description: Bjack is a simulation of the card game Black Jack. The player takes it up against the bank and can determine for himself how much money he wants to start with and how much he wishes to bet each round. The normal Black Jack rules apply, both the dealer and player receive cards and must say when to stop. If the total value of their cards exceed 21, they're busted. The player whose cards are closest to 21 wins the current round. The rules in the game include "double" (double the bet, but receive only one more card) and "insurance" (pay half your bet and get paid 2 to 1 if the dealer has Black Jack).
title: Bjack

description: Brick is a one-button game in which the player must prevent a brick from breaking a window. The brick is thrown at the window with a variable speed. Halfway its flight the brick will turn invisible. The player can stop the brick in mid-air and any given time by pressing the Y button. The closer the brick is to the window (without breaking it) the more points the player scores. Breaking the window costs the player many points. The average of all throws counts.
title: Brick

description:
In this Battleship variant, the player fights against the AI. The player may place four ships of two, three, four and five tiles large. Ships can be placed both horizontally, vertically and diagonally on the grid.

Instead of only one shot each turn, players receive a number of shots depending on the ships left. Some ships count for more shots than others. Only once the player has fired all shots is he or she notified of hits and misses, so that the player does not know which shots were the hits. The player wins if he or she manages to sink all enemy ships for the AI does the same.

sample_screenshots.caption: I can only fire two shots having lost two of my ships
Game over, I lost. Wait, what, his boats where crossed over each other!?
I have some random hits, but I don't know which shells hit

title: Bship

description: In Guess the player must guess a number between one and a hundred that the computer has memorized. To do so the player must give a low and a high number to which the computer will answer whether the number is below, in between or above the given range. To aid the player a matrix of numbers is visualized and all numbers that can no longer be correct are crossed out. The game remembers the number of tries it took the player to find the correct number.
title: Guess

description: Hangman is a digital version of the traditional pen and paper game. The player must guess a word of which only the length is known by naming letters. If the letter is correct the player is told the location(s) of the letter within the hidden word. If the answer is incorrect a limb of a human is drawn, if the entire human is drawn he's hung. This game features very little options. The player cannot set any settings and does not keep score. The game does show a list of all letters that have not yet been guessed.

sample_screenshots.caption: I'm all hung up with this game
Only the head is drawn so far

title: Hangman

description:
Hman is a digital version of the traditional Hangman pen and paper game. The player must guess a word of which only the length is known by naming letters. If the letter is correct the player is told the location(s) of the letter within the hidden word. If the answer is incorrect the player gets a mark. Reach the limit of marks and it's game over.

This version of the game doesn't have any hangman graphics, but does let the player determine the difficulty by choosing the maximum number of marks. The game visualizes both letters that have been correctly and incorrectly chosen, and letters that haven't yet been chosen.
title: Hman

description: Ian's Speed Race is a simple racing game with eight different tracks. The game uses a top-down perspective and the car drives automatically. All the player has to do is steer left and right to avoid hitting the edge of the tracks which instantly destroys the race car and use the number keys to shift gears to increase speed. The goal is to stay alive for as long as possible while racing laps.
title: Ian's Speed Race

description: The goal in Maze is for the player to find all the gold hidden inside a maze. The game will generate a maze randomly and the player can stop the generation at any time to determine the size of the maze. Inside the maze gold will be hidden at various spots. Some spots feature more than one piece of gold which means the player must also visit the spot more than once.
title: Maze

description:
Mind is a Mastermind game. The player must guess a sequence of four colors within a self-defined maximum number of guesses. There are six different colors, selected by inserting their first letter. Once a sequence is guessed the computer will say how many colors are correct and at the correct position, and how many are correct but not in the correct position as hints for the next guess.

The game maintains an average number of guesses the player takes to find the solution.
title: Mind

description:
Quix is a Simon Says-type game. The computer will show a sequence of numbers in order with different dial tones. The player must then repeat the sequence using the numbers on the numpad. With each correct sequence the computer will generate a new sequence that's one tone longer.

The game keeps track of the longest sequence that the player was able to correctly memorize.

sample_screenshots.caption: Tones are marked on a grid resembling the numpad. It's more fun than it looks!

title: Quix

description:
Slot is a slot machine simulation. The player gets to play behind a simple one armed bandit. All the player has to do is say how much money he or she will bet, the slots will then turn and if the player is lucky a prize winning combination will pop up. When there's a price the player receives a number of times his or her bet in return.

The player can bet anything between 1 and 5000 per round and keep going forever. The game keeps track of how much money the player is ahead or behind. Unlike real slot machines this one is calibrated to break even.

sample_screenshots.caption: one cherry gives back half your money

title: Slot

description: Wander is an interactive toy that lets the player play with a wandering worm on the screen. The player can make the worm pause and continue, determine its size and the character used to define the body. There are no specified goals.
title: Wander

description:
Est is an educational game that requires the player to estimate the size of line segments on the screen in centimeters. The player is allowed a 1.25 centimeter error margin.

Before starting the game it's possible to calibrate the game so that the actual lengths given actually correspond with the screen size of the player.
title: Est

description: Vector Chase is a textual game in which the player must chase a randomly moving object. The game plays out in turns and the goal is to capture the object by coming within 25 units of it. The information given to the player is the x and y locations of the object and the player, the velocity of both and the direction (in degrees) in which the object is traveling. The player must enter in which direction he or she wishes to travel. The game keeps track of the number of turns it takes the player to capture the object. There are 9 difficulty levels.
title: Vector Chase

description: Wipeout is a dice game of chance. The player starts with a bar with the numbers 1 through 12, the goal is to play them all away.
